description:
Sponsor: Thermal Grizzly Aeronaut on Amazon https://geni.us/e8Oq & Hydronaut (Amazon) https://geni.us/hOQrBAb
The NVIDIA GeForce RTX 5090 GPUs launch next week, but reviews can go up today. This benchmark and review of the RTX 5090 Founders Edition video card evaluates the gaming performance vs. the RTX 4090, RX 7900 XTX, RTX 3090 Ti & 3090, RTX 2080 Ti, and more. AMD has an RX 9070 and 9070 XT coming up, which will likely aim to compete in some capacity with NVIDIA's Blackwell RTX 5070 and/or 5070 Ti. For launch though, NVIDIA will ship the RTX 5080 and 5090 on the same day. These benchmarks look at rasterized gaming performance, ray tracing, power consumption and efficiency, thermal testing, acoustics, and Schlieren imaging of the 5090 Founders Edition cooler.

Watch the tear-down! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IyeoVe_8T3A
We have a ton more content coming up on this card, so check back regularly over the next few days and subscribe!

Watch our thermal engineering interview with Malcolm Gutenburg: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-p0MEy8BvYY
Find GN's test bench details here: https://gamersnexus.net/features/living-doc-current-test-bench-hardware-list-methodologies
12VHPWR is a Dumpster Fire: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y36LMS5y34A

The best way to support our work is through our store: https://store.gamersnexus.net/

Like our content? Please consider becoming our Patron to support us: http://www.patreon.com/gamersnexus

comments.text: I’ve coded my own buy BOT in a foolish hope I’ll be able to beat other buy bots and get a 5090 from nVidia’s website on release day.  I’m a pretty good software engineer so I think I have the best possible bot code to win the battle, but it’s also very possible nVidia will do a fake release and really only send shipments to those with very large orders once again leaving the retail channel effectively closed and open to scalpers and markups.  I had a laugh at the people trying to sell the 9800X3D for $750 and they saying delivery date is end of Jan or early Feb … the lengths people go to for a few extra $$$ … can’t help thinking that would be better spent on an education and a real job path.

comments.text: No one is mentioning multi-monitor support as the 4090 can only handle 2 4K monitors at 240Hz. Can the 5090 do 3? If so a reason for me to upgrade.  Given that even higher refresh rate monitors are coming out I am surprised this is not covered.  People play regularly with 3 monitors for games like MS Flight Simulator so u cannot ignore this major feature which enthusiasts care a lot about.  Even ASUS has monitors with well over 400Hz refresh capabilities.  Let me state the obvious, people that can afford $2k for the best GPU can also afford spending money to get multiple high performance gaming monitors with refresh rates at or above 240hz.  Also please don't argue that most people games at only 4k 60hz, that makes me laugh given 4k 60hz monitors came out in 2015 and now it's 2025.

comments.text: @ I do find it interesting with “humans” claiming they can detect a difference for anything above 75Hz refresh … every study ever made indicates no one can identify change in an image above 75Hz but so many insist on 120Hz, 240Hz and higher??  Too funny.  Anyway, back to reality, the 4090 could only achieve 2x 4K monitors at 240Hz with DSC enabled (display streaming compression) which reduces image quality … far more noticeable than 120Hz vs 240Hz.  The DP ports on the 4090 are DP 1.4a with one HDMI 2.1.  DP 1.4a can’t do native 4K 240Hz without DSC.  Tell you what, lets test you on 75Hz, 120Hz, 240Hz with an image that displays for 13ms and lets see if you can notice it … when you can’t detect it, will you stop the 120Hz and 240Hz insanity?  But hey, I’m sure the marketing teams at LG, Samsung, ASUS, Alienware will surely convince you that you gain detect 240Hz over 120Hz over 75Hz … let me sell you a bridge $$$$

comments.text:
The 5000 series gpu should now be dubbed the "youtuber edition". Because they’re the only ones isolated by any of these real world problems - price, availability, free shipping and exceptional direct product support -- and maybe sponsorship fees.

We only get hyped by feeding us their glowing reviews of these sponsored product and some very mild psa from them - as to not offend their paying sponsors while showing placebo effect of public service to their audience.

So now we not only have fake frames, we get disingenuous hyping of products as well.

Us normal consumers have to contend with hyper inflated prices, very low availability and lack of support when these items break.

Consider this, what would they say if they didn’t get any sponsorship or available cards from nvidia to "review" their new cards? We might instead get 15 second psa's of tldr.

comments.text:
I think the focus of this review should have been making plain and understandable the complexities introduced with multiframe generation.

Some big questions Im left with:

What is the latency hit of MFG at different native FPS? This is the biggest downside judging from Hardware Unboxed's review.
When is MFG usefull? 
What are the visual artifacts introduced with MFG?
- and artifacts with the new DLSS transformer model?

How will it impact the sound volume of the PC with all the extra power consumption?

Basically help me judge wether MFG is worth the price, especially at the "lower end" GPU's in the 50 lineup moving forward.

All these questions are about what visual fidelity and what volume we get from a build. 

I'm especially concerned about the volume of a system because watching a beautifully shot movie with a loud fan next to my face is not how I would ever be able to enjoy it, and its not how I can enjoy a good videogame either. I think we are making a huge mistake when compare PC components at max load instead of standarized to a nice and quiet volume. I dont care what the max FPS is if thats the fans running at max, which is always incredibly jarring.

comments.text: To me, the RTX 5090 is just a 4090-Super-Duper. They got the extra performance by giving it more power and a bigger price tag. No improvement in performance-per-dollar or performance-per-watt is just not impressive to me. The only impressive thing here is that they got this MEGALODON GPU into a 2-slot card without issues. The 5080 looks decent but if its going to be faster than the 4080-Super than the 16GB of VRAM might be a little bit low. The 5070-Ti is the card that makes sense to me this generation. It should offer 4080-Super Performance for $250 less and thats just a win. The 5070 12GB once again doesn't have enough VRAM so Ill probably recommend that people looking at a card near $500 - go check out AMD 9070/XT instead. So ya, 5090 for 1% club, 5070-Ti for most gaming Enthusiasts, and AMD for lower budget. Seems like a pretty open-and-shut case.

comments.text:
I just read about schlieren imaging and I could be way wrong but this is my take:
Light that comes from the source, hits concave mirror and back to camera, the focal point of the mirror is where you put a knife edge.
Now when light goes through the air as it encounters a different refractive index (more or less dense air due to turbulence) it bends and changes direction, getting blocked by the knife edge either partially or completely making that light absorbed by the camera sensor in that part of the image darker. I guess the longer the path, the more sensistive it is.

comments.text:
phenominal depth, you're doing an amazing service to everyone
I feel like with the comical frame rates in even rasterized 4k, the 5090 is overkill for the majority of gaming scenarios. I personally am interested in a 5090 (maybe far into the future when I have the funds) for rendering in blender. I've said it before and I'll say it again, I am kind of confused as to why you do blender renders for CPU tests, when blender's cycles engine runs a million times faster on a GPU than a CPU, as it is nearly endlessly parallelised. Blender renders in CPU reviews give us part of an idea of the cpu's capability, but blender renders on a GPU review would be instrumental in my own purchase decision. 3D art is perhaps a niche market, but it's where these high end GPUs should shine. I would really love to see blender cycles as part of the testing suite, more than any game

comments.text:
The idle power draw difference is likely mostly going to the big 32g of gddr7.
There is probably a minor architectural efficiency improvement in load, but small enough the 32gb of ram is eating it up.
Overall, your 5090 results are 'extremely' similar to what I was expecting. Which makes me feel pretty good about my ability to read tea leaves from design specs.
+30% (a bit more in heavy RT) for +25% price, with no noteworthy power efficiency change on the same process node & largely unchanged cuda architecture.

Overall 5090 at msrp is 'slightly' better than a 4090 at msrp in price per frame ...IF your wall outlet can handle it (In my case, i have 2 rooms on an aging 1800w line, and I doubt it could handle a 5090 along with everything else in the 2 rooms).

I also really like the new FE cooler. I wonder if the liquid metal will be present in other cards, further down the price ladder?

comments.text:
The Schlieren image shows a huge temperature differential and an obvious void where the vents are channeling the airflow away from the centre of the card as Malcolm mentioned in the previous vid. Very cool indeed!

The issues with a blow through design are 1) you CANNOT mount 2 GPU side by side. The GPU will ingest the hot exhaust from the other GPU and/or 2) the CPU & RAM will be blasted with hot exhaust at >50C (my guesstimate.)

Even if you use an AIO for the CPU, the RAM will suffer, even if you have a blower like the Artic Liquid AIO or a RAM blower like the Gigabyte Aorus Master/Extreme motherboards. I'm not too worried about the VRM temp at all though. RAM, however, can be overclocked with lower latency and THAT will be an issue with a furnace exhaust.

With 32GB RAM, the 5090 cannot do "AI Training", it is great for "AI Interference"  though since the 24GB on my 7900XTX can just barely fit the smallest models for Image Gen on ComfyUI.

Since I'm not making money from Image Gen, I'm not gonna buy the 5090. I am however interested to run 2 GPUs in my system. 1 for gaming (upcoming 5080 or 9070XT) and 1 for AI Inference (my 7900XTX.)

Very interested to find out the value proposition between the 5080 and 9070XT.

Nice video.  Really like the airflow video capture.  One tip… use a riser to move the card away from the whole system.  It will show just card airflow patterns.   Also consider overlay real video with the airflow and blend the together.  Make the GPU look normal with overlaying the air movement.  Also experiment with applying a colour range filter, darker shows red  with lighter shades as blue maybe?   Try not making this look like a thermal image but something like it.  Try different colours for the right effect.  I think this would help highlight the flow changes in your captures.

I’m still 50/50 about getting one to replace my 3090… we shall see!

comments.text:
Kena 50s 3060, 3070 80s 1440p

F1 60s 3060, 3070 100 1440p

New world 1440p 3060 70s, 3070 100

Flight sim 1440p, 3060 40s, 3070 60s

Forza 3070 4k 100,3080 130 on average 

Hitman 3070 60s 4k, 3080 80s

4060 4K tsunama at 25 fps, 4070 40s no DLSS 

Elden Ring no DLSS 1440p, 4060 40 fps, 4070 70
 
 
  4080 Forza 4080 110 fps, 4080 140 4K

Avatar 4k 50fps 4080, 4090 70

Hogwarts 4080 4k 45s, 60 4090
 
As you guys can see, I compared models directly under a higher class, as that's the only way it makes a higher class worth it since the jump will be bigger, which is why it makes no sense to compare a 4090 to a 5090 only 1 gen apart. It only makes sense to compare the 4080 to the 5090, which will skip the 4080s; this way it shows a good jump. The same goes for coming from a card like mine, 4070, to the 5080 or 4060 to 5070.

comments.text: Been checking most common reviewers including Jay's and we all agree on one thing.....the 5090 is great tech but its also flawed by the scandal which forces users to head into AI generated frames because without this, these cards and previous generations underperform greatly with RTX on. When game developers stop creating light and shadow rasterization, it might be the end of an age of gaming altogether and instead bring in a new aged smudgy mess with lots of AI generated artifacts on screen. Who is willing to lay down these amounts of prices has to be out of their minds for the game and content isn't even worth playing most of the time due to the serious amounts of game breaking bugs. Let stand alone the mountains of promises developers give before release. Bottom-line .....it isn't worth it anymore and possibly lots of people stop playing videogames altogether. Let's go back in time and remaster some old jewels which where broken on release due to probably bankruptcy. GoG knows:trophy-yellow-smiling: I mean.....someone was bold enough to make an Free to download (do donate please) AGA version of Turrican II for the Commodore Amiga 500+  and it looks just awesome in WUAE (emulation). This is a peace of nostalgic software in where developers where pushed towards creativity to get the most out of their limited technology and the results where mind breaking achievements during this time of pioneering. Nowadays.....AI generated content is available for everyone, its killing off artists by the numbers both in music, in coding, in 3D design, concept design. Give and take that a standards ROM for the Super Nintendo was about 3MB in size and it would give you easily 40 hours of gameplay with a game like final fantasy 6. Nowadays, 160GB games attract people with lots of entourage and advertisement, by the time they proceed further into the game the game breaking bugs and lame story development makes gamers quite most games. Speaking of MORE IS LESS...yes....obviously. More content doesn't mean its good, it just shows that the base content is lacking depth so they rely on DLC to keep people chained to their product. Marketing is endorsing the game industry but its also killing the game creative spirit alongside its revenue based targets.
comments.author: @acco724

comments.text:
Hardware review industry: 
Hmm, how are we going to measure framerate in an age where Moore's law simply is not applicable anymore, given that the gains need to come from smart usage of dedicated tensor hardware, algorithms that are backed by many, many research papers and proof-in-the-pudding results that speak for themselves?

Steam hardware charts: 
Seems people (or their nerdy friends, at least) very much understand the value add of ML based upsampling and reprojection methodologies, and how tensor hardware can be used to accelerate/improve them.

Digital Foundry in total geek mode: 
And here is how it works under the hood, and this is how the various upsampling results look like (quality DLSS and XESS often reconstructing better than native, FSR known to be fizzle city), and here are the artifacts of the intermediate generated frames (which seems hard to notice for both DLSS and FSR, great!), and this is the impact on latency.. oh, and we're making sure to focus on comparing DLSS vs DLSS without going into the FSR vs DLSS framerate comparison territory, as we understand people still want to also know about DLSS gains!

This review: 
... Yeah, no ... we're still gonna just completely ignore that DLSS exists in 2025. Mah apples!1


You could've done an apples-to-apples comparison of DLSS (_all_ titles benchmarked in this review support DLSS) by just either comparing DLSS inter-generationally (20xx vs 30xx vs 40xx vs 5090), comparing it intra-generationally (setting the 5090 baseline here for later 50xx reviews) or even SFG vs MFG (like DF did). Ignoring the technique completely and acting as if ML based upsampling/frame generation is just a 'subjective preference' that card owners may or may not want to use casually ignores a lot of the science and the math behind the way it works (it's not just Bob-Ross 'let's paint a happy little tree here', you know 🙂) and the reason why dedicated tensor hardware on GPUs exists in the first place.

Don't get me wrong: Nvidia definitely overplayed their marketing hand by trying to hide the lack of pure generational flops uplift by shuffling around all the marketing bits and bobs until you only saw DLSS results (and seems to try to make us forget the 40 series Supers exist in the process :p ) ... but this review seems to do the opposite by stubbornly only presenting the data that will pull everything down to the lowest common technical denominator, and pulling a 'la la la, I can't hear you' on the reality depicted by Steam's hardware charts (I'm sure some are going to paint a misanthropic narrative around that, but everyone (including mainstream gaming news) knows where to find DF these days 😀).

I'm not sure what the intention of the ML choices in the perf section of this review was: yes, despite Nvidia's attempts we all knew upfront that raster-vs-raster results were going to be lackluster, what with limited flops % increases (often matching or only slightly outpacing price % increases) .. but what's the point of only representing this observation? People who only play non-DLSS games might be tempted towards the underdog by this narrative, but they are still going to mentally add 'but the 50xx comes with DLSS' when it's time to pull the wallet out. And people who want to actually use the tensor cores hardware that exists on a device (the audacity!) got .. what did they really get from this review? 

To top it off, the conclusion at 35:50 contradicts itself, as it states the review (which does not show any DLSS numbers) proves that the DLSS-specific marketing numbers from nVidia are factually incorrect; how does that statement even begin to hold water? Apart from this, the conclusion tries to pedantically argue that the marketing slide's clear and prominent technique depiction should have been placed in the title (which doesn't even work, as a variety of non-generalizable permutations are used) and just casually/misanthropically assumes the viewers of a presentation that's in large part about DLSS4 and MFG would not know (or be able to find out from the same presentation) what DLSS 4 is or what MFG entails ...

Look, we all want the underdog to start competing again, but as consumers we really shouldn't be doing the job of AMD's marketing department and Intel is showing corollary that dedicated hardware units for things that are not rasterization are simply the way forward (at least until ASML high NA EUV can .. hopefully .. create more breathing space). In the end Nvidia is also hit by the end of Moore's law, so even Nvidia is going to have a harder time convincing 40xx (or even some high end 30xx) owners to upgrade to 50xx (don't worry: people who upgrade this often know to wait for hardware reviews when hearing "5070 has 4090 performance" marketing babble).

I'm sure many (myself included) respect the technical prowess Gamers Nexus consistently shows in their review methodologies .. and the Schlieren imaging, the FE cooler analysis and teardown stuff is all great. But the conclusion and the choices regarding ML based comparisons for the mainline perf data section (the part where the review itself even indicates that everyone timestamp-jumps to) ... man, despite really not wanting to read it this way, I have to admit it's hard to not read it like a giant Jen-Hsun beef piece providing fodder for the 'fake frames' crowd ... and we've already got too much anti-intellectualism going on in the world as it is. 😞

Maybe time to join the wider industry in their attempts at constructively representing the future direction of graphics from a technical perspective rather than ignoring it wholesale, before viewership starts following the Steam hardware charts delineation?

The cynic in me is half expecting this to become Greg-ified (avid GN followers will know) .. but that's fine; if it helps in at least crossing the threshold and resulting in new and interesting ways to measure things (disregarding from whether it paints a positive or negative picture), it'll be worth it.

comments.text:
Looking like with the bit of a price jump, my 4070ti will manage throughout this generation (or at least until prices and availability stabilize).  I've only upgraded from 3xxx to 4xxx due to high resale of 3xxx cards.  I could sell my 4070ti today for $800, having paid $1150, and purchase a 5080, netting myself hopefully a decent upgrade for sub$400 after a 2 year ownership of the 4070ti .  12gb has only faltered in Indiana jones maxed out, my 8gb prior 3060ti rarely ran out of core speed before memory was an issue as well.  Both cards were just fine if settings were managed properly in like 2-3 games, and full throttle maxed in most others at 1440p.

Given the prices of these high end cards, why would we not treat them the same way we should ANY multi thousand dollar purchase.  I don't buy a car without knowing and appreciating all the features.  I'm most interested in the Nvidia broadcast upgrades, the ai dude that aids you in a stream, massive encoder upgrades and playing around with the new dlss swapper tool.  Did anyone even watch the keynote?  Why is nobody talking about any of these?  I know it's a little early in the review cycle due to shelf prices not being known, but no mention at all does seem contrary to what a review should be.  They are valuable features, i.e., I would pay money for them alone if they weren't included in my gpu purchase.

comments.text:
Kena 50s 3060, 3070 80s 1440p

F1 60s 3060, 3070 100 1440p

New world 1440p 3060 70s, 3070 100

Flight sim 1440p, 3060 40s, 3070 60s

Forza 3070 4k 100,3080 130 on average 

Hitman 3070 60s 4k, 3080 80s

4060 4K tsunama at 25 fps, 4070 40s no DLSS 

Elden Ring no DLSS 1440p, 4060 40 fps, 4070 70
 
 
  4080 Forza 4080 110 fps, 4080 140 4K

Avatar 4k 50fps 4080, 4090 70

Hogwarts 4080 4k 45s, 60 4090
 
As you guys can see, I compared models directly under a higher class, as that's the only way it makes a higher class worth it since the jump will be bigger, which is why it makes no sense to compare a 4090 to a 5090 only 1 gen apart. It only makes sense to compare the 4080 to the 5090, which will skip the 4080s; this way it shows a good jump. The same goes for coming from a card like mine, 4070, to the 5080 or 4060 to 5070.

comments.text: The noise spikes are very likely due to what is known as blade pass frequency (BPF). It's the fan rpm x no. of blades divide by 60. So for 7 blades @ ~1580rpm that gives 7 x 1580 / 60 = 184Hz. You will then see smaller spikes at harmonics of this, so 184x2=368Hz , 184x3=552 ...x4, x5, etc. We sometimes use this at work to indirectly measure a fans rpm just by looking at the sound profile with a spectrum analyser. Neat.

comments.text:
I think I have a way to explain how schlieren photography works.

When light passes through different mediums, say from air to water, it will slow down. if the light is entering at an angle, the speed change will cause the angle to also change. 

At certain angles light can bounce completely on the boundary between 2 mediums because of the difference in their densities. This is total internal reflection. At shallow angles, light will bounce off the boundary, but if the angle get steep enough, light will pass through the boundary. This is called the critical angle.

What schlieren photography is doing is taking advantage of the different densities of either the way air flows, or how it expands due to temperature Causing the light to either bounce go into the camera or away from it, causing a difference in brightness. This is what allows us to see the movement of the air.

Do you mean the 2080 Ti? I was very pleased to see it covered. 2 - 3 generations is by no means obsolete, especially not the highest-end card.

People need to remember to think in terms of generations and not years. Until the 20 Series the avg. generation gap was 14 months, so that a 3-generation-old card was 3.5 years old. Now the gap is 24 - 28 months. A 3-gen-old card is now 6+ years old --- but it's still just a 3-gen-old card.

Improvements aren't made by years, they're made by generations.

comments.text:
To anyone curious enough about the way he viewed the exhaust. 

Basically he's shining a light/laser of a specific wavelength that will show the distortions of air from the heat generated by the GPU. 

Since the GPU is constantly cooling itself. The direction/turbulence of visualized heat and airflow can tell us how good or bad the cooling system actually is. 

Warmer air expands and cooler air contracts, that causes pressure difference in the air that also "visually" warps the air, but the camera setup and light he uses makes it easier to visualize the warps and wefts of air and heat,

comments.text:
The problem is you want it to be a fair race, when it hasn't been a fair race in quite a while. First it was just Nvidia vs. AMD, now it's Nvidia vs. AMD vs Intel and vs Nvidia again because the feature sets are growing so quickly it has now made the generations not comparable in a typical use case. And that really matters. Typical use. Theoretical maximums don't really matter if the average end user will never use the card in the fashion you test it at. What matters is actual use. How will the card perform in a typical gaming session. For the fake frame crowd, you're 100% correct, but I'd argue that fake frame crowd, based on AMD's market share, as AMD has basically designed its cards - to its own detriment you could argue - to cater to the native no RT no upscaling, no nothing crowd, isn't the average end user.

Steve do you really, honestly, think the average end user for Nvidia products are playing without framegen/MFG on... which I'd note are on by default in any game that supports it. If so, then your argument is valid, they should be showing native raster numbers. If not, if they are going to simply install the game and click play and never tweak settings unless something goes wrong (which seems a lot more likely), then you're marketing material should 100% show how people are likely to be using your product. You market to the majority, not the minority. If the majority are using those feature (or are likely to based on past actions) there is little to no value in showing results that don't apply to them. Especially when they know there is an entire section of Youtube who will provide those numbers for those who actually care?

It's a pain point you're going to have to get used to, because Intel is just going to do the same thing, and if AMD ever decides to accept that they've been catering to the minority, they likely will to. Native raster just isn't the gold standard it used to be when you start including these feature sets.

comments.text: Schlieren photography explaned as basic as I can make it: Light bends because of density changes (hot and cold air have different density), it doesn't hit the knife edge as expected. The result is bright and dark patterns that reveal the invisible density changes.
comments.author: @Rageypeep

comments.text: Would it still work with something other than a blade? Does the thin-ness (in the direction perpendicular to the light's path) of the blade matter, or does it just need to be a very regular straight edge?
comments.author: @johnnypopstar

comments.text: @johnnypopstar  anything with a fine edge will work, blades are used because you know they way they are made they are very fine with few umpuities along the edge. Now, you can also get the same effect using filters in post-processing, as long as you're using the RAW footage, you could get your editing software to do it for you. All the blade is doing is blocking part of the light at the focal point where it's been bent by density changes, making those changes visible. One other way is by using a small, precise light source (like an LED with a pinhole), you can skip the knife edge entirely. So there are other ways around it.
comments.author: @Rageypeep

comments.text: @Rageypeep  appreciate the info, thank you!

comments.text:
Why can't nvidia figure out how to structure the performance and pricing of the 80 and 90 lines to sell both to the right demographic? The 3090 was basically a 3080ti for gamers, so naturally nobody wanted to pay 100% more for it. They learned that lesson and provided a noticeable performance difference in the 40 series, but they neutered the 4080 too much for its 50% price gain and underpriced (relatively) the 4090 for its performance. That merely switched which line had the better value, not make both good valuable for different use cases. 

So, for the third attempt, pending the 5080 benchmarks, they widened the performance gap even further, with a more logical price difference comparable to the 30 series, but I fear the performance gap is so significant that the 5080 is in the 70 Ti space and is still probably overpriced. Why squish the 70 and 80 series closer together? If they gave the 5080 80% of the 5090's performance, 20 or 24GB of memory, and a $1400 msrp, it'd be in the correct spot. 20% more performance for 40% more cost is a reasonable ratio for the highest, top end, which has traditionally had a worse value than the next spec down. Cramming 3 lines so close together makes no sense as gaming performance is not consistent enough for specs that similar to justify the price differences. The 70, 70 Ti and 80 all cater to the 70 demographic and most of the 80 demo would probably rather buy a 90, justifying the expense with performance longevity.

comments.text:
Well they now control the entire price and market process (as every consumer industry does now) and what I mean by that is that they set the initial price of a card, let's say the RRP is £2500 then, prior to complete control, you would have seen a gradual decline in price over the course of the year so, normally, you would have seen a price drop just before the release of the next gen production line so you could potentially grab yourself the same card for a sizable discount, i.e. £1000, or less. But now what's happening is that they control this price via scarcity, marketing and complete control over stock (forward and back) so the price now remains relatively constant and in some cases you can even see an increase in price of the old gen product line when it should be available at a reasonable discount. What is happening is that companies now pull the old stock before the release of new stock so nothing can be bought at a discount therefore preventing/denying consumers the option of going with a half-price old card but instead will then be more pressured into looking at the newer stock. It's disgusting and it's the consumer who loses out, year in year out.

It's the exact same in all other markets, cycling, sports, etc. For example, in cycling, new bike range is released and the moment it is you can no longer buy the old range as the company have, with alarming speed and coverage, cleared ALL of the old stock from ALL online stores so you are forced out of potential bargains and instead are coerced into buying the new range. It's beyond vile but this is the new face of business and AI is telling them what and when.

comments.text:
I really would have loved to see how the 5090 performed on a closed case. I know that's not how you test but I guess that the amount of heat this card produces under load is significant enough to consider at least a side test, just for reference. It would have been important to know how the heat affected GPU throttling and also how it affected other components.

I'm especially concerned about how the redirected exhaust heat affects the VRM components of the CPU and the M.2 SSD that is typically inserted under the GPU, as I understand that there are two flaps that moves the heated air on both sides of the card, not just the side that's facing the case glass or cover.

Open test benches are great for the world records and for finding the true raw performance but they're not representative of everyday use for most consumers.

comments.text: Vortices and magnetic fields behave the same way, this is why Schlieren works. And since vorticity changes air density, since turbulence is a bunch of little vortices with little low pressure cores at the center. Turbulence tends to be slightly different density than the air around it. And by splitting light with a sharp corner, you create more light diffraction, just like sharp corners create vortices in airflow.

comments.text:
Sorry Steve, I like you but that "article" comes off as whiny, vindictive and not at all like the bomb you thought it was. You were better off saying nothing at all. I mean come on, bringing up stuff from years ago like them not crediting you, then telling you how they were gonna address with it no objection from you, they do what they said they'd do and now years later you're still complaining? Come on man, that's not. receipt, that just makes you look  petty. As for unprofessional texts, seriously? That's how people text in private texts, you chose to make it public and all it looks like is that you disagree over something and he's trying to move on but you can't let it go 

That article doesn't make you look good at all man. It makes it look like you've got a personal axe to grind without any real ammunition to throw at him. Furthermore, you didn't address any of the complaints Linus made in his WAN response, particularly about the Billet Labs issue and the whole thing about wanting to meet him but only if Luke is present...do you think he's gonna take a swing at you or something? Yeesh. He wasn't making veiled threats either. He's pretty clear that he has no interest in taking this into the realms of legal action. But maybe you do and maybe you should if you feel that strongly about it. Or maybe you should take a step back, take a breath and reevaluate. 

Everyone here likes you dude, they're gonna tell you what you want to hear, not what you need to hear. You're free to ignore this of course. I like you both equally for different reasons and frankly you both annoy me for different but also equal reasons (you're right about him being sloppy, he's right about you not following journalistic integrity with regard to right of reply). Maybe you've got people around you telling you "Yeah man, you really stuck it to him" but when I read it, all I thought was, "that's it? There's nothing here." If he responds again on WAN, my advice is to ignore it or if you can't, listen carefully before you choose whether or not to respond and try not to listen with a mindset of "he's out to get me" because frankly the way it looks right now is that you're the one who's out to get him and that kind of mindset is going to hurt you and nobody wants that.

comments.text:
With the latest Cyberpunk update, the DLSS version has been upgraded to 310.1.0.0 (nvngx_dlss.dll). By copying this DLL file into the folder where any DLSS-supported game’s executable file is located, we might be able to use the latest DLSS version across all games. However, the DLSS Swapper program hasn’t received an update yet.

In Cyberpunk 2077, we can now switch the DLSS model from the old CNN-based method to the new Transformer model. If this model switch is necessary, developers should consider adding this option to all DLSS-supported games in the future.

On another note, the ghosting issue (trailing effects on moving objects) has been significantly reduced, which is great news. As an RTX 4080 user, the best part of the RTX 5000 series is that we’ll also benefit from DLSS 4. For those using RTX 3000 cards, keep an eye on updates—there are rumors that NVIDIA might bring Frame Generation to the RTX 3000 series as well.

Comparing the 4080 to the 5080 is not a fair comparison because the 4080 super was cheaper than the 4080 and out performed it and is the latest version of it. comments.text: The 6800XT handles starfield quite well with maxed out settings and at 4K. AMD has all those optimizations that make the game run very well and with my B550 32GB DDR4 setup it runs with 52 FPS average (with an 5600X CPU). In many instances with maxed out settings at 4K I can play even with 133 FPS and more. It is really about settings and setup as well. I would say that the 5090 with 32GB might be interesting for some deep learning and what not, the whole 5000 series seems great, but for everyone who has something decent or recent, there is no point updating yet. I would wait a year or two till the next gen or something new from AMD. comments.text:
The 4k gains looking like 27 to 35% gains average (I do not think lower resolutions matter for anyone but competitive tournament players and speed runners). And with Ray Tracing, those gains are slightly bigger. I think 30% is acceptable, with 40% being the goal, and it appears to be more of the former.

Hoping driver updates make it easier for developers to take into the great vRAM, the cache changed and GDDR7 technology (namely the 4x or so increased bandwidth) to further push this card over time.

GDDR7 is still in its infancy, so hoping as it matures Nvidia, AMD, Intel and Qualcomm can use drivers that developers can properly utilize to use the extra bandwidth to get better gaming results in frame rates, frame pacing, frame smoothing, and dramatically improving the 1% and 0.1% lows.
comments.author: @faceurhell

comments.text:
Also want to say some of these lower end performing games are terribly optimized. Starfield (a game I really like but I am unable to love) is awful with rasterized performance (and loading times) despite subpar graphics.

These games are good for the charts and information, and uplifting terribly optimized games is important, but having to compare it to a game that is optimized for the card like Cyberpunk or an incredibly optimized game like the Resident Evil 4 Remake is sort of like comparing Oreo’s, oranges and apples respectively. All 3 are still very important in their own ways to have.

comments.text:
I'm not sure what prevents the 40 series from having DLSS 4 other than to encourage you to buy a 50 series. I would expect 50's to still outperform 40's on DLSS 4, but It would nice to see that. 

In general I think we have to update our testing methods to account for DLSS and Frame gen, need a subjective way to compare generated frame quality. If me as a gamer can get way better FPS at the same perceived quality levels I don't really care if it's due to upscaling, frame gen, or whatever. We may have just reached the end of big generational rasterization improvements and that's ok as long as we are getting more frames at the same or better quality.

It would have to be some sort of AI that can compare the same full 4k frame with the generated upscaled frame and report the number of errors. I imagine NVIDIA has something like this internally as thats essentially how you would train DLSS models in the first place.

comments.text:
Great Review - one thought from me, I know the current gaming test suite has mostly been chosen because these games are more recent, typically have heavier workloads, and show scaling the best between different resolutions, ray tracing on/off, etc... however I would like to ask if the GN team could reconsider putting some "esports" or even just more multiplayer types of titles in these charts, even if they mostly get glazed over quickly. I feel like these types of games are way less represented than they used to be in the test suite.

There are a lot of gamers out there who mainly play multiplayer types of games, and I find it hard to explain to people who are looking at new builds that while yes, a new card like a 5090 might show an average uplift of 30%, that may not actually mean anything for you if you don't tend to play these new top of the line single player games releases that tend to really push the hardware in your system to the limit. I know there are other sources out there, but I tend to trust these benchmarks the most and I think it could be helpful for a reasonable portion of the gamer population to not feel pressured into upgrading to new hardware when these new products get released.

comments.text:
NVIDIA made Intel's mistake... Almost a complete refresh of the previous generation, and it even performs worse at lower resolutions, where it should be significantly faster. I really don't believe that the NPU matters. This DLSS4 doesn't look good at all from the first tests where it's in games. Lots of glitches, non-existent objects, screen division into equal parts...
And the consumption...

For me, the 5000 series is a worse scenario than Intel with its new processors and the new socket. It's the same prices, then consumption, bugs (at least for now) and a co-pilot video card, for nothing more. And for the gaming industry, I think this last one is already becoming unnecessary, given the latest news coming from the game development sector!

A complete failure, in my opinion!
That's why AMD waited so as not to fall into the trap of poor competitor performance, as was the case with Intel.

And one more thing. This video card manages to consume more electricity, on average, say per month, than a two-room apartment without a computer. It is somehow unconvincing to tell people that NVIDIA worked for some kind of ecology at all... Boiler, stove, lighting, TV, AI connectivity, monthly with normal use do not manage to reach 400 watts per hour. While this video card, alone, is capable of pulling up to 600 watts CONSTANTLY under heavy load, not in games, and I do not play much, but for the activities that I perform with the video cards, not crypto or AI things... I have been testing it for a week and I definitely will not keep it. Average consumption for the week, just from the computer outlet, provided that I work on it hard, amounts to a little over 420 watts per hour throughout the week...

I definitely will not replace my 4090 with this 4090Ti, with oops 5090...

And I definitely regret, still, that I decided to replace three computers with 3070 with one with 4090...
The consumption is higher in the end, because, for example, I can run three different tasks on the three computers, which even with 5090 cannot be completed in the same time, run sequentially!

I made a mistake!

Let my experience give direction to those who think that such a video card will save them time! It will save space, yes, but time...

comments.text:
With the release of the RTX 5090, NVIDIA has introduced a flagship GPU that comes with a $500 premium over the RTX 4090 while delivering a 30% performance boost at 4k. If I were to speculate, the 5090 feels like what the 4090 Ti might have been if it had ever launched. While it does pack a few extra features and upgrades, the overall value proposition becomes questionable for those who already own an RTX 4090.

For existing 4090 users, the performance uplift doesn’t seem compelling enough to justify the steep cost of upgrading, especially considering the diminishing returns at the high end of the GPU market. Unless you’re someone chasing the absolute cutting edge or needing the latest features for a specific workflow, the 5090 appears to be more of a lateral move at the premium tier rather than a game changing leap forward.

comments.text: Explaining FLIR imaging as shown around the 11 min mark: In a nutshell a specific frequency of light is shown through thermally excited air and reflected back at the camera by the mirror. With correct distancing, mirror type, and light frequency, this creates an Optical Doppler effect determined by the density of the air the light is passing through, and this allows the camera to capture the air flow. That's all there is to it, if not a bit oversimplified. (This is for those who are wondering how it works and don't want to read a lengthy wiki article, so don't @ me.)

comments.text: Once again, Nvidia marketing lies, but the flagship card still looks decent.  Whether or not you can say the price is fair though is much harder to say.  It has good specs in terms of everything but power consumption/efficiency, but like $2000+ is still crazy for a GPU, just to try and play Cyberpunk (or similar games) @4k with ray tracing.  It's getting really hard to justify high end gaming in this economy, this is a pay to win card for rich people or professionals.  Unfortunate that we've gone from historical flagships like the 1080ti costing $700 (which adjusted for inflation is ~$910) in 2017 to the 5090 costing $2000 in 2025, a nearly literal doubling in cost. Meanwhile, the 3090 was $1500 ($1820 when adjusted for inflation) in 2020, which is not nearly as steep as an increase, but is still a  10% increase in cost.  It seems more and more that high-end gaming is just for the rich.  Flagship Nvidia cards really aren't for average gamers anymore...sigh.

comments.text:
@Nazgul094  nah man, you just found the guy who is sick of people parroting the same braindead garbage without any reasonable level of substance. 

Starfield has its quality mechanics / quests, but was let down by poor exploration as they bit off more than they could probably chew in the 1000 planet galaxy design, but it also has some stilted dialogue delivery and some characters in the game, while even having some sense of depth, the way it was delivered was often flat. They also just generally didn't do the best job at getting the player 'excited' about having an adventure in this massive galaxy, and that's a strange misstep I feel, but its a galaxy that feels 'thin'. 

I feel some of the complaints about having any general loading times is ... like look, I get it. I do ...  but with modern systems (SSDs), you load into an area in like 5 seconds. Didn't bother me much. 

The ship building portion was quite enjoyable though and they did a commendable job with it, but they could have expanded on outpost building to feel a bit more meaningful. 

The quests have some bright spots and in particular, a few of the faction quests 'are' pretty enjoyable. The main quest is one of my biggest core criticisms also since I can't stand multi-verse narratives since they lack any sense of weight and often feel like a bit of a cop-out? 

Anyway, all this is to say that I tend to roll my eyes at comments without any meaningful sense of substance to them. Carry on.

comments.text:
My Theory:

CUDA Cores, SMs, RT cores doesn't scale linearly with performance, ex. how the RTX 4090 having 60% more cores than the 4080 is roughly 30-35% faster than the 4080. (4090 most likely limited by L2 cache and memory bandwidth)

There is a certain amount of memory bandwidth that benefits performance in most games, beyond that limit the performance doesn't seem to be impacted. Memory bandwidth sensitive games like cyberpunk 2077 sees the biggest uplifts of around 40-50% which can take advantage of the 1.8TB/s memory bandwidth of the 5090 where as other games which sees only a mere 20-25% uplift aren't taking advantage of the bandwidth of the RTX 5090 because at a certain amount of bandwidth (lets say 1.2TB/s, anything more than this doesn't impact performance in those games)

Maybe future titles might be more memory bandwidth sensitive and we'll see an average of 40-50% uplift for the 5090.

comments.text: Pretty much 100% safe, even in a sealed case with no airflow at all. Because for quite some time now, GPUs and CPUs can thermal throttle. But in a serious scenario...As long as you have decent airflow, this shouldn't even be an issue. Understand that just because the GPU or the VRAM is 80C, doesn't mean the air in your case is 80C. More like it'll increase your case air temp by a delta of 10-20c from ambient room air temperature. So basically who cares.

My 7900XT Nitro+ in a high airflow cases with an air cooler can kick out enough heat to make my DDR5 unstable when gaming. The only way to fix it is crank the GPU fans. It's stock VBIOS keeps the GPU in check, but leaves more heat trapped in the case making my DDR5 10c hotter with stock fan curves. comments.text: I've been really itching to see the FPS/W because subtracting all the marketing BS I suspected that there wasn't much, if any, performance gain in that area between 4090-5090.  After watching this video, I feel like my hunches were vindicated.  nVidia has hit a wall.  Sure, the 5090 gives 20-35% more performance, but it does it at the cost of consuming more power and the chip taking up more space on the PCB.  The generational improvements have been diminishing more and more with each new generation.  nVidia is doing a lot of boasting with their products; but that's just to hide how close they're teetering on the edge. Without those generational improvements, there's no flagship products for them to launch, and it can capsize their company if they don't play their cards well enough.  It's a race between the rate at which a newer and better transistor technology can be invented, and how fast nVidia's bank account is being drained.

No one with a 4090 should be upgrading to a 5090 if you do you're an idiot.

No one who IS upgrading should be trying to upgrade to a 4090 at its current cost and limited availability with the 5090 on the market now, simply put if your shooting for halo products the extra couple hundred are worth it.

If you're a 4090 owner no reason to feel bad your not losing value yet. If your a 5090 buyer no reason to feel bad either your paying one to one for the dollar to performance and energy cost uplift your getting compared to the 4090.

Expecting a generational uplift every time that leaves the last gen with buyers remorse is weird and most of the people who are thrilled about it are likely 4090 owners who are just grateful they don't need to feel buyers remorse "yet."

Finally new tech is always a consideration but only once it's been established and demonstrated, it's not really an objective point for or against a product pending large scale testing and evaluation, which is why it's a good thing I suppose that this product at least matches cost scaling parity.

For people not on 4090, it's really just: can you afford it or can you not afford it, do you want the best or not, or do you have a need for it. comments.text:
@ 

You’ve acknowledged you’re an outlier—if you truly need the hardware for work, or the cost is basically pocket change to you, then by all means, go for it. For most people, though—middle or even upper-middle class—the time saved isn’t worth the expense. You’d need to be earning at a level where you can recoup a flagship GPU’s cost in about an hour’s pay (which is multi-millionaire territory) for it to be a purely logical decision.

That doesn’t imply you have a low IQ. When people say a choice is “idiotic,” they usually mean the cost-to-benefit ratio is unreasonable, not that the person is perpetually clueless. Plenty of hobbies can look “idiotic” from a practical standpoint—like partying all weekend—no one’s denying that. If you are going to throw serious money at hardware upgrades, you’ll see far more tangible gains investing in a high-end storage system with a dedicated RAID card and Optane caching than chasing every new flagship GPU just for a few seconds shaved off load times. Still, if you really do earn enough that this purchase is inconsequential, then sure—go for it.

comments.text:
​​ @Eepy-Rose Nvidia's GPU software allows you to force frame limit any game to almost any FPS cap which is not a feature AMD has. Capturing indie games that are poorly configured means I would often find games trying to eat every ounce of GPU power to render uncapped, competing with my model rendering and capture software.

Nvidia Shadowplay feels far more straightforward than AMD's newer competitor component for capturing video.

I mentioned VR latency and there are some anecdotal experiences that VR has had two bugs with AMD's drivers, one increasing latency on older drivers prior to the December 2024 release but this newer driver causing hitches when rendering so no matter what it's likely running VR suboptimally for no particularly valid reason other than lack of AMD support.

More specifically software like LIV for VR runs awfully and there's no fix in sight. More games and software seem to, by default, support compatibility with Nvidia first but I have no real proof of that just my own experiences.

There's also a bug with the newest supported Video Codec for AMD causing the wrong resolution to encode and apparently there is no fix or solution because it's a bug that shipped embedded with the physical card itself and can't be overwritten but you might need to Google that one. Supposedly fixed for next gen cards but it did NOT inspire my confidence in AMD

Overall a lot of odd niche issues but it's been frustrating. I think for 99.99% of consumers, these aren't issues, but for me? It's pushing me back toward Nvidia.
comments.author: @LunaSolarys

comments.text: @LunaSolarys  Yeah for me the one that's most concerning is capturing at the wrong resolution. I've heard about that and hoping it does actually get fixed.
comments.author: @Eepy-Rose

comments.text:
@LunaSolarys  Yeah, are AMD drivers better than they used to be? Sure, but are they as good as Nvidia's? Absolutely not. You'll be running into far more troubleshooting nonsense the more you try to use the card for anything other than straight gaming. With Nvidia, by and large, I put it in my system and update the drivers. After that I never have to think about it again, it just works. With AMD I'm always running into something here and there and I just don't have the time or patience for troubleshooting anymore. We're paying a lot of money for this stuff, it's not to much to ask for it to just work when I'm dumping a grand into something. Nvidia offers that more than AMD does, period.

comments.author: @TheDarksideFNothing

comments.text:
​​ @rogerl1569 The point is it will have meant they waited 2 years and potentially spent a lot more money for the same performance. That doesn't seem like the "smart" move to me.

If you're stuck with a 5090 as the only option for the performance tier you want it's gonna be either hot as hell or very disappointing in terms of generational gains.
comments.author: @TheDarksideFNothing

comments.text:
@TheDarksideFNothing  you are not wrong, i totally agree with you. Except hindsight is 20/20, but while waiting for 50 series, no one knew it would turn out like this. So it's not a "If" you are stuck with this performance tier, it's just "you are stuck with this performance tier". Unfortunately there is no competition.

If people who are below the 40 series right now knew this back then, I think most would've went for 4090 instead of waiting till now. Especially if they could've found one at MSRP instead of scalper prices.

Now it's either buying 4090 used (which still seems to be hovering around MSRP), or buying limited remaining stock at scalper prices. With the new 5090 now out, I don't really see any reason to not upgrade, if one is looking for an upgrade to the top tier performance card. Yes the dollar/perf basically stayed the same, while the total $ amt increased. But anyone that was "not smart" enough to move to 4090 back then, this is the second best choice without any meaningful alternative, other than used or remaining 4090.

This comes back to my original comment that it's irrelevant to discuss whether limiting TDP is a bad decision or not. Because the 4090 boat has for the most part sailed already, so to limit or not limit is moot for the people who aren't on the 4090.

comments.text: My question for that dual flow through.. so its pushing air up near the CPU?  Why would not the fans be situated to push the air down instead of up?  Taking the air which comes in towards that CPU and shares it with the GPU, the air which then blows through the CPU area gets exhausted out the back.. and that which blows DOWN via the GPU would go out a different direction.. I know cases are pushing air up with fans on the floor, but they could be blowing air out as well, exhausting air through the floor.   Thereby not blowing warm air up into the intake of the CPU cooler.. and the ASUS 5090 with its extra 4th fan, does that then prevent warm air from flowing up to the CPU intake fans?  And if its a matter of a couple of degrees difference does it really matter?

comments.text: 0:45 the 1080p bind may be a matter of "round trip time" between CPU and GPU at this point. Every draw call causes some communication between CPU and GPU that locks the CPU thread for a moment. So the total "GPU time" per frame is basically [task complexity]/[GPU speed) + [round trip time]. As the GPU speed increases towards absurd amounts, the total GPU-time asymptotically approaches the round trip time.

Present new price of an XTX in the UK is £840 (120% cheaper than the rip off Nvidia card) and the absolute cheapest second hand one on E-bay that has actually sold (IE a completed auction) is £650 with most over £700. That's circa 80% value retention in our market.

comments.text:
As a hopefully helpful reminder for the primarily gaming audience of tech channels: the main selling point of this card is VRAM, which doesn't scale linearly for the arguably main audience of this card - local AI enthusiasts. 

For these tasks, it's not "30% more speed for 30% more money". Modern models are big and don't always fit whole into VRAM, but as soon as you overflow into system RAM, your speeds slow down to a crawl. So for cases like these, your "30% more VRAM" results in, like, "300% more perfomance". 

So, yes, it is overkill for gaming and "not worth it" (unless you have endless disposable income). But for other tasks, yes, the existence of this card is justified even at this price point... just because there are no alternatives.

comments.text:
​​ @NahBNah Volts x Amps = Watts

Afaik/IIRC/ELI5 for the rest of this:

Computer parts tend to be run at a constant voltage. Power limiting caps the wattage by capping the amps. So voltage is the same but amps can't go as high as at stock settings. This often affects performance a lot.

Undervolting is specifically just reducing voltage. So the amps run the same as at stock(oversimplified) but the voltage is lower, therefore the wattage is also lower. Voltage mostly affects stability rather than performance(oversimplified). 

If the specific piece of silicon you got  happens to be particularly high grade it can run on lower voltages without crashing. Because you lowered the overall wattage, though, you have less heat. Which allows for thermal headroom and therefore better performance.

Hope this helps and makes sense haha

Also, one problem with undervolting is the behavior will often be different from one GPU to the next even if they're they same model. One 5090 might undervolt better than another 5090 because of the "silicon lottery." It's generally a great thing to do if you like to tinker, no real down sides if you dial it in and don't overdo it. But your mileage may vary with how much it actually helps you.
comments.author: @TheDarksideFNothing

comments.text:
⁠ @NahBNah  

Power is measured in wattage using 
Power = Current * Voltage or (P=IV)

So if you limit voltage, then current needs to increase. If you limit current, then voltage needs to increase (only applies assuming it will use the same power draw).

comments.text:
Yeah. 25% more performance for 20-25% more price (no card appears in the wild at msrp) and almost exactly 25% more power.

So we're looking at a generational uplift of 0-5% performance... How is this not a headline on every freaking site and youtube channel on the internet? This is a complete disaster.
comments.author: @RoadRunner217

comments.text: @RoadRunner217  I guess it is, if you upgrade every gen. If you skip gens and are looking at the uplift from say the 2080ti or 3090, then where is the disaster? Now, I think if the card was 1599 like the 4090, it would be a much, much better proposition. But like most things, it proves the outlook of, don't upgrade every gen. The 2080tis were in the 1100 to 1400 range and for most of it's life, the 3090's where in the 1500 to 2k range. So, if someone is will to spend the money, this is a great uplift for them. On the other side, if you already have a 4090, then it's a bad uplift to buy this the 5090. It's sort of like everything else. If you have a 78X3D, then the 98X3D is a waste of money to upgrade. If you have a 5800X3D, then the 9800X3D is a ok uplift and if you have a 5x00 non X3D or older, it's a huge uplift. Everything is perspective that is tainted by how people WANT to view things, instead of applying the same logic equally.
comments.author: @joee7452

comments.text:
@joee7452  I wish more people would look at things this way. I want to think all the people mentioning the marginal updates over the 4090 already own a 4090. Otherwise, they are just arguing for arguing's sake.

meaning the 5090 is a 4090 TI , the 5080 is a 4080 super and so on. The Problem with Nvidia focusing on Gimmicks or AI for performance is that 

it encourages developers to be lazy and relies on unoptimized games and for us to use AI to fix the problem.. we need raw performance no matter what because if its just AI , then what happens when your game natively runs sub 30 and you want to use AI the frame-gen will run poorly no matter how much you turn on reflex 2 etc .

we need a node jump like the leap we had with the 3090 to 4090... the 4090 will become the new 1080ti... until we get down to 3NM or 2NM  which will take years, so if your on a 30 to 40 series skip this gen and wait for the 6090 or 7090.

comments.text: @rocky258258  AMD has on average had less major driver issues going by patch notes in the last 3 years than NVidia IIRC. On Linux NVidia drivers are still a complete joke with constant major issues that take eons to be fixed (I had dithering broken for half a year so I had a grid pattern across my entire screen without using external tools to get rid of it or disabling dithering entirely and ruining my monitors image quality lmao). AMD drivers on Linux have been flawless in my experience and issues usually get resolved quickly. Even considering the trash drivers, without NVK games still run better on Linux than on Windows, even when they don't have actual Linux support and you're just running them through Proton/Wine. NVK is a whole entire world in some scenarios (IIRC there was some game that ran over 100fps better than on Windows with it, on a 4090), but NVidia still very much doesn't give a crap about properly supporting their products if you aren't an enterprise customer spending millions on a single order. Also games with trash Vulkan implementation tend to run slightly worse on Linux (like CS2), but if anticheat isn't an issue you can usually run them through Proton without issue and get better performance by translating directx to Vulkan on the fly lol.

comments.text:
I bought the Sapphire 7900xtx nitro+ close to its launch and I’ve been very happy with it.

Only driver issue I’ve had was a day 1 space marine 2 issue that they patched within a few hours. At the time I got around the issue by turning one in game setting down for that level. I had far more issues with my previous 5700XT, though I never found them so frustrating or intrusive as to make me dislike the card. (It, btw, is happily driving a pc for my partner to use on her beloved but ancient 720p plasma TV that I can’t get her to give up because of its frankly still amazing black levels and color depth).

People point to “work” abilities of NVIDIA cards, but most gamers aren’t doing that stuff. If all you want is affordable 4k 60fps gaming, it’s always been the best card on the market.

One feature I appreciate from Sapphire is they have a hardware side upscaling solution called Trixx Boost, built into all their nitro cards. It lets you set any custom scaling you want for any resolution. I have mine set to 90% of 4k, as this matches the resolution I can perceive (playing in my recliner about 7 feet from a 60 inch screen). So far every game runs at ultra settings.

People talk about Ray tracing, but the 5090 can’t do cyberpunk 4k ultra RT at 60 fps without frame generation either. There just isn’t a card that can do no-compromise 4k 60fps RT yet, and on the occasions I want RT I’ve found I was still happy with the compromises I choose in settings to get my target fps from my 7900XTX.

If you’re buying anything from AMD I really believe the Sapphire Nitro+ version is the only way to go.

Edit: fwiw I do cut videos in Premier as a secondary task for my job. These are usually social media length, with the very occasional longer YouTube cut of a town hall or something. Between my 5800x3d and 7900xtx I can export a premier project of 1-3 minutes in 4k 60fps in about 1-3 minutes. 

I’m usually still setting up the email to notify my boss it’s in her cloud by the time it’s done. If you aren’t a full time video editor, the reality is anything in the 7900xtx/4080 tier is massive overkill. I just don’t think you’ll notice the extra 30-60 seconds saved for the $1,000 more
